title.narrative: GLA Viet Nam: Srepok River Basin in Central Highlands Landscape

description.narrative: For 2017, Tropenbos Viet Nam will focus on two main areas, capacity building for local CSOs, CBOs including the GLA’s partners, and support L&A process for better participation/involvement of local CSOs, local community to forest law revising and policies under forest law development process as well as natural forest protection from high pressure from cash crops encroachment. We are working in Central Highland Landscape, but in the year 2017 the GLA will concentrate only two provinces (Lam Dong and Dak Lak). Tropenbos Viet Nam will cooperate with IDH/ISLA program to apply “Landscape Approach” to participatory land use planning at Gung Re commune, Di Linh district, Lam Dong Province. Through this activity, Tropenbos will provide training to local CSOs, including farmer union, women union, and private sector who are acting in the area. The guidelines of Landscape Approach at local level will be developed accordingly. We will cooperate with university, research institute and local CSO (provincial VUSTA) to establish “regional forum for natural forest protection” which promote information sharing, and facilitate L&A for better forest governance in Central Highland landscape. Several training courses on “conflict resolution”, “L&A and communication skils”, and “Gender in natural resources management” will be provided to local CSOs. Tropenbos will cooperate with provincial VUSTA, WASI, University, and mass organizations (Women, Youth, Farmer, Veterance…) in Lam Dong and Dak Lak province to carry out the GLA activities in the year 2017 and the following years.

The Green Livelihoods Program in Viet Nam works in the Srepok River Basin in the Central Highlands of Viet Nam. The Central Highlands straddle five provinces and represent a distinct agro-ecological region in Viet Nam. The Srepok river flows through four of these provinces in Viet Nam before it continues into neighbouring Cambodia. The area was chosen for several reasons. First, the Central Highlands are one of the 7 key agro-ecological regions of Viet Nam, with a wide variety of land-use types such as agricultural production (especially agro-commodities such as coffee, rubber, tea, cacao, pepper, cashew, etc.), forestry plantations, animal husbandry, irrigation systems, hydro-power plants, protected areas, watershed protection forest, production forest, and residential areas. Secondly, the region faces major challenges in natural resources governance as a result of rapid expansion of intensive agriculture that contributes to the destruction of natural forests and pressure on other ecosystems: the Central Highlands are rich in biodiversity but many animal and plant species are threatened. Thirdly, the Vietnamese Government has selected the Central Highlands as one of two key regions (besides North-West region) in Vietnam in need for intensive investments toward sustainable development.

The Green Livelihoods Program strives to change policies and practices, thus contributing to (1) proper conservation and management of existing natural forests; (2) sustainable production practices in coffee, pepper, cassava and other agro-forestry commodities that don’t lead to further deforestation and depletion of water resources; and (3) the implementation of integrated landscape approaches to natural resources management that involve the voices and interests of civil society, local communities and of men and women. To achieve this, partners will develop a “landscape agenda” for the Srepok River basin to engage donors, financiers, NGOs/CSOs, private actors and local communities. The aim is to bring these actors together to collaborate in the transition to sustainable production and landscape management practices. Successful examples of good practices will be monitored, documented and publicised. Community and Civil Society organizations will be empowered to participate meaningfully in these dialogues, collaboration and decision making processes, and links with the media will be strengthened to highlight issues and best practices. Gender sensitive and inclusive approaches are prioritised. The Theory of Change shows three distinct pathways that lead to the realisation of these objectives. The GLA will capacitate partner CSOs to generate and use evidence; and facilitate engagement and collaboration between government, private sector and civil actors in inclusive multi-stakeholder dialogues. The development of effective and inclusive advocacy and lobby actions is prioritised in order to change policies and practice.

2.2: Companies and farmers apply best practices, such as Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA)/ agroforestry, green infrastructure and achieve net positive impact on ecosystems and livelihoods (23 in ToC)
The level of engagement, commitment and action (ECA) of the targeted public or private actor.

description.narrative: The level on the ECA tool demonstrating a change in the policies/practices/behaviour of targeted public and private actors. Scale: 1 = no interest, 2 = awareness and receptiveness, 3 = agenda setting, 4 = concrete steps to improvement, 5 = improved policies, guidelines, etc. approved, 6 = poor implementation (of good policies, laws, etc.), 7 = moderate implementation., 8 = satisfactory implementation. A more detailed description of this scale can be found in the added ECA tool (pdf).

comment.narrative: Coffee companies have shown interest to make investments in pilot farms for Climate Smart Agriculture (CSA). To promote these practices coffee companies have had initial discussions with the Provincial People Committee, who seem to actively take a lead to promote CSA.
Three Coffee companies (Olam, Louis, ACCOM) operating in Di Linh District have taken steps to applying CSA go for green product with agro-forestry production
Olam Coffee company recommended local people in Di Linh district to apply techniques for sustainable coffee production/plantation.
Coffee companies in Dak Lak and Lam Dong Provinces invest and adopt Climate Smart Agriculture/agroforestry, green infrastructure by 2020

comment.narrative: Dak Lak and Lam Dong provinces show an active interest in promoting CSA and cooperate with several development projects to apply CSA in the region
Lam Dong and possibly Dak Lak provinces decide to scale up spatial planning and CSA recommendations to other districts
NA
Coffee companies in Dak Lak and Lam Dong Provinces invest and adopt Climate Smart Agriculture/agroforestry, green infrastructure by 2020

title.narrative: Change in level of participation/ capacity/ operational space of civil actors in landscape governance, access to land (rights) and nature-based approaches

description.narrative: The level on the Civil Actor Participation (CAP) tool demonstrating a change in the participation/ capacity/ operational space of civil actors: scale 1 = no participation. no capacity to influence/participate. no operational space. 2 = passive participation (informed). limited capacity to influence/participate. limited operational space. 3 = small scale/piloting participation. some capacity to influence/participate. some operational space. 4 = involvement/active participation. capacity to actively influence/participate. more favourable operational space. 5 =partnership/collaboration. capacity, means and operational space to influence or participate as equal partners.6 = leading role for civil actors. civil actors fully capacitated and acknowledged for having the leading role in a safe, conducive operational space. A more detailed description of this scle can be found in the added CAP tool (pdf).

comment.narrative: Farmer associations in Srepok landscape (Dak Lak and Lam Dong) are not sufficiently informed and trained to be aware of need for CSA in the Central Highlands.
Farmers unions in Srepok landscape are aware of the need for CSA
Farmers association in in Gung Re commune, Di Linh district (Lam Dong province) intercropped fruit trees with coffee plantations
Local farmers in Lak and Krong Bong apply Information, knowledge on the best practice of agro-forestry models to boost local livelihood improvement.
No reported outcomes yet
Farmers associations facilitate CSA among members and government in Dak Lak and Lam Dong province

comment.narrative: There is willingness by the DPC of Di Linh to start a participatory land use planning
District People Committee of Di Linh accepts the results of spatial planning and agrees with private sector to invest in CSA

title.narrative: 2.4: Government adopts policies that contribute to reduced deforestation and forest degradation (21 in T0C)
Change in level of participation/ capacity/ operational space of civil actors in landscape governance, access to land (rights) and nature-based approaches

comment.narrative: CSOs are facilitated and equiped to involve in policy development process in CH, and actively participate in implementation of the new policy
CSOS, CBOs participate in multi stakeholder platform about CH forest policy and contribute to the national policy development of natural forest conservation and improve degraded forest.
NA

Local CSOs are actively involved in policy development process and facilitate local community contribute to the national policy development process on forest protection and restoration of degraded forest

title.narrative: The level of engagement, commitment and action (ECA) of the targeted public or private actor.

description.narrative: The level on the ECA tool demonstrating a change in the policies/practices/behaviour of targeted public and private actors. Scale: 1 = no interest, 2 = awareness and receptiveness, 3 = agenda setting, 4 = concrete steps to improvement, 5 = improved policies, guidelines, etc. approved, 6 = poor implementation (of good policies, laws, etc.), 7 = moderate implementation., 8 = satisfactory implementation. A more detailed description of this scale can be found in the added ECA tool (pdf).

comment.narrative: Dak Lak and Lam Dong provincial authorities are prepared to carry out specific policy of forest protection in Central Highlands with participation of civil society and private sector. Provinces are under the guidance of CHSC to pay more attention to forest protection and landscape restoration

VNForest has prepared strategies for forest protection in CH, based on PM decision Provincial authorities (Lam Dong, Dak Lak) have developed their action plan to implement these strategies Central Highlands Steering Committee sends a clear message about the importance of forest protection to the provinces MARD creates multi-stakeholder dialogue platforms to advocate for improved implementation, investment and enforcement.

State forest owners (forest companies, forest management boards, national parks) realised that forest deforestation and degradation were due to incomplete forest law and policies, and made recommendations for policy improvement.

Through networking and multi-sector alliances, multi-stakeholder dialogue platforms will function to advocate for improved implementation, investment and enforcement. These platforms should become the key structure for discussing policy change, investments and coordination.

title.narrative: 3.1: Government adopts and implements an integrated spatial development plan and EIA, which includes and balances the interests of development and community livelihoods and conservation (17 in ToC)
Change in level of participation/ capacity/ operational space of civil actors in landscape governance, access to land (rights) and nature-based approaches

description.narrative: The level on the Civil Actor Participation (CAP) tool demonstrating a change in the participation/ capacity/ operational space of civil actors: scale 1 = no participation. no capacity to influence/participate. no operational space. 2 = passive participation (informed). limited capacity to influence/participate. limited operational space. 3 = small scale/piloting participation. some capacity to influence/participate. some operational space. 4 = involvement/active participation. capacity to actively influence/participate. more favourable operational space. 5 =partnership/collaboration. capacity, means and operational space to influence or participate as equal partners.6 = leading role for civil actors. civil actors fully capacitated and acknowledged for having the leading role in a safe, conducive operational space. comment.narrative: CSOs, CBOs have little chance to involve and understand about landscape approach in natural resource management, especially forest, land and water resources.
CSOs, and partners in Dak Lak province adopt experiences from Landscape approach used for PLUP in Lam Dong province.
No reported outcomes yet
NA (unexpected outcome)

People’s Committee (CPC) requested Di Linh District People’s Committee (DPC) of Lam Dong province to integrate their Macca trees development plan into the land use planning (LUP) currently carried out by TBI Viet Nam in Gung Re commune. This is the first time that local people actively took the chance to raise their voice/demands on land use based on the PLUP process to be considered in the spatial plan preparation.
CSOs, CBOs from Srepok river basin are actively involved in integrated spatial development planning with landscape approach.

title.narrative: The level of engagement, commitment and action (ECA) of the targeted public or private actor.

description.narrative: The level on the ECA tool demonstrating a change in the policies/practices/behaviour of targeted public and private actors. Scale: 1 = no interest, 2 = awareness and receptiveness, 3 = agenda setting, 4 = concrete steps to improvement, 5 = improved policies, guidelines, etc. approved, 6 = poor implementation (of good policies, laws, etc.), 7 = moderate implementation., 8 = satisfactory implementation. comment.narrative: Discussion on the establishment of a Srepok river basin management authority are ongoing. There is a need to have several provinces along the Srepok river basin work in a coordinated manner to regulate the water flow, hydropower generation, irrigation, and landscapes.

DARD/DONRE have started consultations with stakeholders on the establishment of river basins management committees for Se San and Srepok river in Central Highlands Directorate of Water Resources (MARD) has planned to establish river basins management committees for Se San and Srepok river in Central Highlands with fully consultation with stakeholders, civil society.

Di Linh District Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DDARD) in October 2017 indicated their interest to apply the landscape approach and the participatory landuse approach (PLUP) of Tropenbos VN in additional communities of Di Linh district. Lam Dong Provincial People Committee (PPC) urged Tropenbos Viet Nam to speed up PLUP for future inclusion into the provincial green infrastructure development plan.
Di Linh District approves Gung Re spatial plan
No reported outcomes yet
Directorate of Water Resources (MARD) place discussion on the issue of integrated spatial development in Srepok river basin on the agenda
No reported outcomes yet
Local authorities in Dak Lak revise socio-economic development strategy with green growth indicators and landscape planning.
No reported outcomes yet
One district in Dak Lak has started to implement PLUP
No reported outcomes yet
NA (unexpected outcome)

People’s Committee (CPC) requested Di Linh District People’s Committee (DPC) of Lam Dong province to integrate their Macca trees development plan into the land use planning (LUP) currently carried out by TBI Viet Nam in Gung Re commune. This is the first time that local people actively took the chance to raise their voice/demands on land use based on the PLUP process to be considered in the spatial plan preparation.
NA (unexpected outcome)

The Minority Groups Affairs Council under the National Assembly made a plan in late 2017 for monitoring the implementation of National Assembly’s Resolution 112, regarding monitoring land use and management by state forest enterprises in 8 provinces, including those in the Central Highlands.
Srepok River Basin management board operational and functioning to formulate and adopt a spatial development plan and implement landscape approach to a moderate/ satisfactory extent

title.narrative: 2.3: Forest owners, Households and communities with allocated forest lands restore and manage degraded forests (24 +25 in ToC)
The level of engagement, commitment and action (ECA) of the targeted public or private actor.

description.narrative: The level on the ECA tool demonstrating a change in the policies/practices/behaviour of targeted public and private actors. A more detailed description of this scale can be found in the added ECA tool (pdf).

comment.narrative: Insufficient allocation of forestland to households and communities of land managed by Commune People Committee. Some are willing to coduct restoration but there is not sufficient land available. State enterprises own large amounts of forest land.
Well trained Forest protection unites in two districts (Lak, Krong Buong) support forest owners, HH and communities to apply for forest land and restore forest on it.
NA
Forest rangers and DARD effectively support communes in FLA and forest restoration in Lak and Krong Buong Districts
No reported outcomes yet
Province, district authorities and forest companies place forest restoration issue on their agenda in 2018.
No reported outcomes yet
Commune People Committees in Dak Lak and Lam Dong allocate sufficient forestland to households and communities

comment.narrative: Local communities and CSOs, CBOs have low level of participation in land use process, and land allocation decision making.
CSOs, CBOs in Dak Lak and Lam Dong have some L&A skills to support local communities claim land title, and resource use rights.
NA
Local CSOs and farmers use information of forestland use conflicts to negotiate with local government for re-allocating forestland to local people and communities.
No reported outcomes yet
Local CSOs in Dak Lak and Lam Dong are able to support local communities to participate effectively in land use planning and forestland allocation process.

title.narrative: 2.5: Government reviews and reforms related NR policies (ICCA, PFES, FLA, FLEGT-VPA, REDD+) (18 in ToC)
The level of engagement, commitment and action (ECA) of the targeted public or private actor.

description.narrative: The level on the ECA tool demonstrating a change in the policies/practices/behaviour of targeted public and private actors. Scale: 1 = no interest, 2 = awareness and receptiveness, 3 = agenda setting, 4 = concrete steps to improvement, 5 = improved policies, guidelines, etc. approved, 6 = poor implementation (of good policies, laws, etc.), 7 = moderate implementation., 8 = satisfactory implementation. A more detailed description of this scale can be found in the added ECA tool (pdf).

comment.narrative: PFES policies are in place, but the implementation process must be adjusted to fit with the demand from communities. PFES receives at this time funding from revenues from hydropower electricity, water supply and Tourism. Payments Into the scheme should be expanded with other users of forest environment services, such as aquaculture in mangrove forests etc. Definitions of the "users" of forest ecosystem services, needs to be clearly defined and based on cost norms and the market (user of ecosystem services).

MARD revised and issued new PFES policy and guidelines to apply with different forest environmental services users. The instruction for implementation is provided to all actors involved and the local communities who are the beneficiaries of PFES.
NA
VNForest and regional ranger office in the CH set up a network of SMEs in timber production and trade under the new Forestry Law and VPA/FLEGT new context and sustainable forest management
No reported outcomes yet

VNForest issues a revised Chapter (belongs to the Draft Decree) on PFES accepting local communities as legal PFES beneficiaries, while indicating a better definition of users (i.e., aquaculture enterprises)
No reported outcomes yet
MARD reviews and reforms related NR policies (PFES, FLA, FLEGT-VPA, REDD+)

title.narrative: 2.1: Government has adopted and implements the new forest law (18 in ToC)
Change in level of participation/ capacity/ operational space of civil actors in landscape governance, access to land (rights) and nature-based approaches

description.narrative: The level on the Civil Actor Participation (CAP) tool demonstrating a change in the participation/ capacity/ operational space of civil actors: scale 1 = no participation. no capacity to influence/participate. no operational space. 2 = passive participation (informed). limited capacity to influence/participate. limited operational space. 3 = small scale/piloting participation. some capacity to influence/participate. some operational space. 4 = involvement/active participation. capacity to actively influence/participate. more favourable operational space. 5 =partnership/collaboration. capacity, means and operational space to influence or participate as equal partners.6 = leading role for civil actors. civil actors fully capacitated and acknowledged for having the leading role in a safe, conducive operational space. comment.narrative: CSOs and CBOs are involved passsively in the forest Law revising process. They do participate in the meetings/ workshops to discuss on few crucial issues of the law which affect their livelihood, but not intensively. Addtionally, CSOs and CBOs have not been provided sufficent information to be prepared for contributing to the law revising process.
CSOs and CBOS have played an active role in the establishment of the new forest law
NA
Local CSOs and CBOs from Lak and Krongbong districts in Srepok river basin have formulated joint inputs for the consultation process of forest policy decrees” (2.1.2b)
No reported outcomes yet
CSOs and CBOs participate in consultation meetings and actively represent their viewpoints

title.narrative: The level of engagement, commitment and action (ECA) of the targeted public or private actor.

description.narrative: The level on the ECA tool demonstrating a change in the policies/practices/behaviour of targeted public and private actors. Scale: 1 = no interest, 2 = awareness and receptiveness, 3 = agenda setting, 4 = concrete steps to improvement, 5 = improved policies, guidelines, etc. approved, 6 = poor implementation (of good policies, laws, etc.), 7 = moderate implementation., 8 = satisfactory implementation. A more detailed description of this scale can be found in the added ECA tool (pdf).

comment.narrative: VNFOREST has started the process of developing a new Law for forestry sector. It is now calling for inputs from a variety of organisations and stakeholders
By the end of 2018, VN Forest approves a CH forest protection strategy (2.1.3a, 2.1.2b)
No reported outcomes yet

By the end of 2018, VNForest releases a Decree guiding the implementation of the articles of the new Forest Law that makes provisions for the adequate participation and consultation with CSOs and CBOs and local communities in forest management activities and in planning.
No reported outcomes yet
VN FOREST will have finalised a law proposal in 2017/2018, consultations for a draft decree based on the new Forest Law have started

The Forest Law preparation committee accepted FORLAND’s recommendations to include local communities in the draft FPDL2017 as legal forest owners.VNForest finalised the forest protection law proposal and adopted the new forest law in November 2017.

VNFOREST has adopted and implements the new forest policy. Circulars and implementing guidelines for the new forest law have been issued. The law or its implementing regulations address participation by stakeholders to forest resources and decision making
